Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis of d- and p-Block Element Molecules, Reagents, and Precursors
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division. Professor Christopher Cummins of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology develops very small, often reactive compounds that occur in interstellar space. An impact of the work is the collection of data needed by radio astronomers to identify new molecules in space. These molecules also serve to enable the synthesis of new classes of chemicals to generate electronic materials or as components of catalysts for use in chemical industry. The work is highly collaborative with study of the new substances conducted in concert with research groups in academia and at national laboratories. The project is a training ground for the professional development of graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral scholars who work together to create new knowledge while exploring and mapping the chemistry of reactive intermediates. Videos of the procedures are posted on YouTube to facilitate adoption of protocols by other researchers and to provide the public with a window into the practice of synthetic chemistry.

This project focuses on the development of molecular precursors that can expel a neutral leaving group, such as anthracene, upon application of a stimulus such as irradiation or thermal activation. This provides a means to generate reactive intermediates such as P2, HCP, SO, or an aminophosphinidene. The reactive intermediate can be transferred to a suitable acceptor molecule for reactions carried out in solution, or released into the gas phase to enable studies by molecular beam mass spectrometry, microwave spectroscopy, and laser-induced fluorescence. Isolated reaction products are characterized by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography, and the experimental work is complemented by quantum chemical calculations designed to reveal details of chemical bonding and to elucidate reaction mechanisms by potential energy surface explorations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chemistry of reactive intermediates can be harnessed to drive the development of new synthetic methods in organic and inorganic chemistry. Fleeting reactive intermediates are of interest for their intrinsic properties, which we investigate using theoretical methods combined with modern experimental techniques. It is possible to generate reactive intermediates as free species, either in the gas phase or in liquid solutions, and to trap them with reaction partners in processes leading to new chemical bonds. Synthetic molecular precursors can be designed and synthesized to be able to release a reactive intermediate upon the action of a stimulus, such as thermal activation, or irradiation with light. It is also possible, in a complementary manner to use synthetic molecular precursors as group transfer reagents to form new chemical bonds.

            We designed and synthesized a molecular precursor capable of undergoing fragmentation into nitrogen gas, anthracene, and a carbon atom. In this system the formation of stable anthracene and molecular nitrogen provide a driving force for carbon-atom transfer to suitable reaction partners. This is a rare example of a carbon-atom transfer reagent. We also used phosphaethynolate as a phosphorus-atom transfer reagent for the synthesis of compounds containing covalent triple bonds between tungsten and phosphorus and showed that a similar chemistry succeeds for arsenic atom transfer to tungsten in molecular complexes, with concomitant carbon monoxide formation. We designed and synthesized an anthracene-based reagent for methylene transfer, with properties to be contrasted with those of diazomethane, in that our molecular precursor is easily handled as a crystalline substance, is not an explosive hazard, and reverses the polarity of the methylene transfer reactions in which it is utilized. Sulfur monoxide is an unstable reactive intermediate for which we devised an anthracene-based synthetic molecular precursor and transfer reagent. In a collaboration with researchers at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, we were able to identify spectroscopic signatures for sulfur monoxide in the gas phase to which it was delivered upon fragmentation of our solid molecular precursor. The same molecular precursor was shown to be a highly effective transfer reagent for sulfur monoxide, with both organic and inorganic acceptors shown to be able to receive the diatomic molecule. This is an excellent example of synergy between astrochemistry and synthetic chemistry. We conducted studies of the reaction mechanisms for singlet phosphinidene transfer from our anthracene-based molecular precursors to unsaturated organic molecules. For phosphinidenes strongly favoring a triplet ground state, we devised and developed a novel iron-catalyzed reaction for phosphinidene transfer from anthracene to styrenic olefins. This is a catalytic method for the synthesis of phosphorus-containing three-membered ring compounds, a long sought reaction realized in this project for the first time. We designed a molecular precursor to phosphinidene sulfide, a little studied reactive intermediate. Thermal activation of this molecular precursor under vacuum led to the driving off of anthracene and hydrogen sulfide gases, leaving behind a yellow solid deposit shown in a study, together with collaborators, to be a new and metastable semiconducting phosphorus-sulfur material. We synthesized molecular precursors to a suite of phosphaalkyne reactive intermediates and carried out spectroscopic studies of them together with our astrochemistry collaborators, with synthetic investigations of their solution-phase reactivity carried out in tandem. We developed a new molecular precursor-based route to acyl-chlorophosphine compounds. Acylphosphines are an important compound class finding application as photoinitiators in 3D printing. We studied reactive intermediates in germylene transfer reactions employing our molecular precursor to dimethylgermylene.    

            These studies formed the basis, in part, for the Ph.D. thesis research of three graduate students. These three students have gone on to postdoctoral studies at Stanford, Harvard, and Cambridge; all three plan to pursue careers as academic scientists. The studies have been carried out with the participation of one woman MIT undergraduate student currently pursuing graduate studies in chemistry at Harvard. Also participating was a Humboldt-funded postdoctoral scholar now employed at BASF and a visiting graduate student from Canada. The studies laid the groundwork for our current and future research investigations, as well as for several ongoing collaborations. Together with our published fundamental scientific findings, the education of undergraduate and graduate students, and the advanced training of postdoctoral scientists and visiting scholars, make up the most significant outcomes from the award. The new reagents and synthetic methods we have developed are now available for use and study by other researchers.

 


Last Modified: 01/14/2021
Modified by: Christopher C Cummins

Fleeting reactive intermediates are of interest for their intrinsic properties, which we investigate using theoretical methods combined with modern experimental techniques. It is possible to generate reactive intermediates as free species, either in the gas phase or in liquid solutions, and to trap them with reaction partners in processes leading to new chemical bonds. Synthetic molecular precursors can be designed and synthesized to be able to release a reactive intermediate upon the action of a stimulus, such as thermal activation, or irradiation with light. It is also possible, in a complementary manner to use synthetic molecular precursors as group transfer reagents to form new chemical bonds. We designed and synthesized a molecular precursor capable of undergoing fragmentation into nitrogen gas, anthracene, and a carbon atom. In this system the formation of stable anthracene and molecular nitrogen provide a driving force for carbon-atom transfer to suitable reaction partners.
